Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my girlfriend’s last message still glowing on the screen: “We need to talk. I can’t keep doing this.” My heart pounded. Our argument had spiraled out of control, and now she was questioning everything—us, our future. I knew I had to call her, to fix this before it was too late. She needed me to be present, to listen, to fight for us.

But just as I reached for the phone, the ER doors burst open. A nurse rushed in, wheeling a patient whose skin was mottled and feverish. “Sepsis, rapid onset,” she said, urgency in her voice. I was the attending on call. The patient’s life depended on my immediate assessment and the right antibiotic—every second mattered.

I felt torn in two. My girlfriend expected me to resolve our crisis, to show her she mattered most. My patient needed me to act, to save a life. Both roles demanded everything from me, right now. My hands shook as I stood between the phone and the patient’s bed, my mind racing, knowing that whatever I chose, someone I cared about would be left waiting.
